newsitem.title: USA: Economist delivers warning on U.S. card debt.
newsitem.headline: Economist delivers warning on U.S. card debt.

text.p: Lower-income Americans are more overextended on credit card debt than other groups, said economist Daid Wyss of DRI/McGraw Hill, who warned of the impact on bank reserves and the economy.

"If this trend continues, banks will be forced to reevaluate loan loss reserves and utlimately it could have a profound economic impact," the economist said in prepared remarks for the National Collections and Credit Risk Conference sponsored by Faulkner & Gray Inc.

Wyss said 27 percent of families whose household income is below $10,000 now have credit card obligations exceeding 40 percent of their income. He said by comparison, fewer than five percent of families earning more than $50,000 are equally burdened.

He said households with incomes below $25,000 are bearing a disproportionate share of accelerating credit card debt, and this may be directly related to the record personal bankruptcies in the U.S. which topped one million last year.
"By extending too much credit to Americans who will have the most difficulty paying it back, banks are forgetting the basic principles of banking," Wyss said.

He said while consumer debt overall has stablized in the past year, outstanding consumer credit care debt as a percentage of disposable income among all Americans has risen to eight percent, which represents a 60 perrcent increase since 1989.
Wyss noted that 50 percent of the largest U.S. banks report they are tightening standards for credit card loans, and about 25 percent of smaller banks are doing the same.

Some participants in the credit card industry have recently argued that while the overall level of credit card debt has risen, many consumers use the cards as a convenience and pay their balances in full each month.
